author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: My Lunch With President Biden
description: I left with a full stomach but a heavy heart.
content: President Biden invited me for lunch at the White House last Monday. But it was all off the record — so I can’t tell you anything he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Powell and Brian St. Pierre
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Can Virtual Reality Help Ease Chronic Pain?’
description: V.R. treatments may provide relief similar to intravenous opioids — a tantalizing prospect for the millions of Americans living with chronic pain.
content: Chronic pain is one of the leading causes of long-term disability in the world. By some measures, 50 million Americans live with chronic pain, in part because the power of medicine to relieve it remains inadequate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Van Den Berg
title: A New Psychological Thriller Explores the Grim Underbelly of Life as a Social Media Moderator
description: Hanna Bervoets’s latest novel, “We Had to Remove This Post,” is a discomfiting mystery about the disturbing parts of social media that most people never see.
content: Hanna Bervoets’s slim, potent new novel, “We Had to Remove This Post,” appears at first to be the story of a tech workplace gone terribly awry, but it quickly shape-shifts into something more surprising and enigmatic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Michigan Mink Mystery: How Did an Interspecies Outbreak Unfold?
description: The puzzling coronavirus cases highlight ongoing surveillance challenges and blind spots.
content: In late September of 2020, captive mink on a farm in Michigan suddenly fell ill. They stopped eating, struggled to breathe and bled from the nose, according to a report from the World Organization for Animal Health. Two thousand animals died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The Rules for Hybrid Work Were Always Made Up
description: As more and more workplaces pause or end the expectation of three days a week in the office, a large-scale return may never be on the horizon.
content: The conundrum facing executives nationwide these days is one familiar to anyone who has ever planned a birthday gathering: “It’s really hard to get anybody to come to a party if everybody R.S.V.P.s maybe,” said Zach Dunn, an expert on hybrid work and founder of the workplace management company Robin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Adam Nossiter
title: A Senior Member of Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Is Killed in Tehran
description: No one claimed responsibility for the assassination of Col. Sayad Khodayee, which took place in broad daylight outside his home.
content: A senior member of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps was assassinated in Tehran on Sunday outside his home, according to a statement by the Guards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Alexander Aguiar
title: These 90-Year-Old Runners Have Some Advice for You
description: Runners at the National Senior Games in Miramar, Fla., competed in events ranging from the 50 meters to 1,500 meters. Their secret? “You’ve got to keep moving.”
content: The scene at the Ansin Sports Complex in Miramar, Fla., was recognizable, not unlike any high school track-and-field meet. There was a practice area where athletes jogged and stretched. There were anxious runners milling about the track and tarps providing shade from the hot Florida sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Félix Auger-Aliassime Can Be an Ideal Champion. First, He Has to Win More.
description: For years, tennis experts have heralded the promise of Auger-Aliassime, a young Canadian. But can he reach the top in the era of Carlos Alcaraz?
content: PARIS — Before there was Carlos, there was Félix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Putting on the Fits
description: Top looks from the Burberry dinner at Lucien, the Gohar World rooftop party and the “Downton Abbey” premiere.
content: It was a week of delicious parties in rarefied settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: France’s Ransom
description: The Times reveals how Haiti became the poorest country in the Americas.
content: Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the world, and a new Times investigative series explores why. One stunning detail: France demanded reparations from Haitians it once enslaved. That debt hamstrung Haiti’s economy for decades — and kept it from building even basic social services, like sewage and electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: Democrats Fight Headwinds in Georgia and Beyond: ‘The Problem Is Reality’
description: Raphael Warnock and Stacey Abrams, viewed as strong candidates by their party, will be running against President Biden’s low ratings as well as their G.O.P. rivals.
content: ATLANTA — Standing at the pulpit of Ebenezer Baptist Church, the spiritual home of Martin Luther King Jr., the Rev. Raphael Warnock led a sermon on the last Sunday before Georgia’s Tuesday primaries that was about “getting to where you need to go” — and navigating the challenges ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 23, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: This is our final “What’s Going On in This Picture?” for the 2021-22 school year. This feature will start again in September.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trump’s ’20 Election Lies Take Root in Statehouses
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 22, 2022.
content: “In 2020, the plan of Trump and his allies hinged ultimately on getting state legislatures to overturn the will of the voters. If past is prologue, that same strategy is likely to be central to efforts to subvert an election in the future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: At Least Six Dead After Severe Thunderstorms Lash Parts of Canada
description: A line of thunderstorms brought violent winds that left a trail of damage across parts of Ontario and Quebec on Saturday, and hundreds of thousands without power.
content: In a grim start to a long weekend in Canada, at least six people were killed and hundreds of thousands of customers remained without power after a line of thunderstorms cut a violent path across parts of Quebec and Ontario on Saturday, according to Environment Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Scorned by Trump, Mo Brooks Rises in Alabama Senate Race
description: Mr. Brooks, a hard-right representative, seems to be making an unlikely comeback in a Senate race in which the Trump endorsement may not determine votes of Trump supporters.
content: CLANTON, Ala. — Two months ago, Representative Mo Brooks, whose hard-right credentials were unblemished, seemed to be imploding in the Alabama Republican Senate race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Justin Thomas Wins the P.G.A. Championship With a Roaring Comeback
description: Thomas, who entered the final round seven shots behind the leader, beat Will Zalatoris in a playoff to win his second career major championship.
content: TULSA, Okla. — The dominant story line before the 2022 P.G.A. Championship revolved around Phil Mickelson, who became the oldest major champion last year when he won the event at age 50 but chose not to defend his title. Then the focus of the tournament shifted to Tiger Woods, 46, who arrived at the Southern Hills Country Club to resume his stirring comeback from injuries he sustained in a horrific car crash 15 months ago. But Woods struggled physically, and mired in last place after three rounds, he withdrew before Sunday’s final round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: A Million Americans Have Died From Covid. We Need to Mourn Together.
description: The magnitude of the loss is overwhelming. Every person who died represents a community, a family or a group of friends who will never be the same.
content: “There is no time to grieve now, there is no time. There is only time for labor in the cold,” wrote the poet Stephen Vincent Benét reflecting on the life of Mary Allerton, who sailed to America on the Mayflower and suffered a stillbirth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: All the Clues That Are Fit to Print
description: Kick off your week with Simon Marotte’s Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s constructor is Simon Marotte, a name we encountered not even a month ago. Mr. Marotte must be busy indeed to be churning out publishable puzzles at this rate — after all, The New York Times receives around 150 crossword submissions per week, according to the senior puzzle editor, Joel Fagliano, so to have two “winners” in such a short period of time is quite the coup for Mr. Marotte.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Review: Henry Threadgill’s Music From Two Perspectives
description: At Roulette, the composer and his ensemble performed a pair of multimedia sets based on a single composition.
content: The most reductive observation I can provide about the composer and improvising multi-instrumentalist Henry Threadgill’s activity at Roulette this weekend is that he debuted some truly exciting new chamber music. Because he offered a lot more, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 22, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 22, 2022.
content: An article this weekend about New York City’s push for local control over street traffic regulations includes outdated information. After the article went to press on Thursday, the State Legislature reached a tentative agreement to extend the speed camera program in the city for three years and to keep the cameras on 24 hours a day, seven days a week, pending a vote and official support from the City Council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Josh Shapiro Defends Primary Ad Tying Doug Mastriano to Trump
description: Mr. Shapiro, the Democratic nominee for governor in Pennsylvania, said he was eager to start the general election campaign.
content: Josh Shapiro, the newly nominated Democratic candidate for governor in Pennsylvania, defended on Sunday a television ad he ran that appeared to elevate the standing of the Republican rival he will face in November — a man Mr. Shapiro has called the country’s most extreme candidate for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Stocks Fall
description: The Buffalo shooting video continues to live online. The Fed releases the minutes from its last meeting, and Netflix lays off some workers.
content: Stocks slid into bear market territory on Friday, the insider term for a drop of 20 points or more from an index’s last peak, before closing slightly up for the day. Even so, the market continued a long streak of losses with the seventh consecutive weekly decline. The pessimism rocking Wall Street stems largely from fears about fast-moving inflation and how aggressive the Federal Reserve may be in trying to bring it under control. Financial statements from Walmart and Target also stoked these anxieties last week, when the companies, both struggling to outpace rising prices, reported taking significant hits in the first three months of the year. The companies’ financials gave investors more reason to believe that the central bank may begin to pursue much larger increases to interest rates, which could tip the economy into a recession. Since World War II, recessions have almost always closely followed bear markets, with only a few exceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods Withdraws From P.G.A. Championship
description: Recovering from leg injuries from a car crash last year, he had struggled at the Masters and now again at the P.G.A. Championship.
content: TULSA, Okla. — Tiger Woods, struggling in his comeback from severe leg injuries sustained in a car crash last year, withdrew from the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Rafael Nadal Is the French Open’s Man of Mystery
description: He was unbeatable at the start of the year, then could hardly finish a match in the run-up to the French Open because of an injury. Which version of the 13-time champion of this tournament will show up?
content: PARIS — Rafael Nadal has a chronically injured left foot that sometimes hurts so much he cannot play.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was My First Visit to the City and I Had an Interview Lined Up’
description: Seeking the No. 6, a parking spot with something on the side and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Easterling
title: At 36, Candace Parker Posts a Triple-Double, a W.N.B.A. Rarity
description: The Chicago Sky player became the third W.N.B.A. player to have multiple triple-doubles in a career. It was only the 11th one in the league’s 26 seasons, and she was the oldest to do it.
content: Retirement may have been on Candace Parker’s mind before this season, but on the court she is showing no signs of being done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Netflix Fired Frank Langella. Was That the Right Thing To Do?
description: It’s unclear what the actor Frank Langella did on his Netflix show. But firings like his can raise complicated questions.
content: The actor Frank Langella tells a story about filming a sex scene on the set of Roger Vadim’s 1988 remake of “And God Created Woman.” Sex scenes are usually “exhausting and a bore to perform,” he explains in his candid and often hilarious 2012 memoir, “Dropped Names.” The sets are crowded, the action slow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Lauren Herstik
title: Lawsuit Accusing Bill Cosby of Sexual Assault Heads to Trial
description: A civil suit accusing Mr. Cosby of assaulting a teenager in the 1970s, which he denies, will be the first to head to court since his criminal conviction was overturned last year.
content: Judy Huth met Bill Cosby when she was still a teenager, she has recounted in court papers. It was the mid-1970s, and Mr. Cosby had already had his breakthrough on the TV series “I Spy” and become a movie star, but was still years away from his huge success on “The Cosby Show.” Ms. Huth and a friend spotted him on a film set in a park in San Marino, Calif., and ended up meeting him in person, according to her court filings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Investigating Haiti’s ‘Double Debt’
description: For a new five-part investigation, a team of Times journalists tabulated the amount that Haitians had to pay France for their freedom and explored how the massive sum still affects Haiti today.
content: In June 2021, Constant Méheut and Matt Apuzzo, two New York Times journalists, arrived in Bordeaux, a port city in southwestern France. They were there to visit the private archive of François Blancpain, a historian who specializes in Haiti, in the hopes that they could begin to answer a question that had been on their minds for months: How much money did Haitians, over generations, pay to their former French slave masters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: On a Remote Mountain, the ‘Sistine Chapel of Socialism’ Awaits Its Fate
description: An enormous monument to the Communist Party in Bulgaria is now a decrepit ruin. The country is wrestling with how to deal with a symbol of an unwanted and, in many ways, deeply ugly past.
content: BUZLUDZHA, Bulgaria — Like most Bulgarians of her generation, the young architect had little interest in or knowledge of her country’s Communist past. But that changed when, during studies in Germany, she got asked about the “big U.F.O. in Bulgaria.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Several Jif Peanut Butter Products Recalled Over Potential Salmonella
description: The J.M. Smucker Company said it initiated a voluntary recall and advised consumers to dispose of some potentially contaminated products.
content: The J.M. Smucker Company has recalled several Jif peanut butter products sold in the United States and Canada because of potential salmonella contamination that federal regulators said has been tied to 14 illnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Amanda Claridge, Archaeologist of Ancient Rome, Dies at 72
description: Her 1998 guide took a detailed look at the city and its many ruins, examining who built what and why.
content: Amanda Claridge, an archaeologist who brought ancient Rome and its surroundings to life — most notably in her often-cited 1998 book, “Rome: An Oxford Archaeological Guide,” which helped inquisitive visitors understand what they were looking at as they wandered that history-rich city — died on May 5 in London. She was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and David D. Kirkpatrick
title: Kushner’s and Mnuchin’s Quick Pivots to Business With the Gulf
description: Weeks before the Trump administration ended, Jared Kushner and Steven Mnuchin met with future investors on official trips to the Middle East.
content: Shortly before the 2020 election, Trump administration officials unveiled a U.S. government-sponsored program called the Abraham Fund that they said would raise $3 billion for projects around the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Saif Hasnat
title: Millions Displaced and Dozens Dead in Flooding in India and Bangladesh
description: Heavy rains have washed away towns, villages and infrastructure, as extreme weather events become more common in South Asia.
content: NEW DELHI — Heavy pre-monsoon rains in India and Bangladesh have washed away train stations, towns and villages, leaving millions of people homeless as extreme weather events, including heat waves, intense rainfall and floods, become more common in South Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Look Good, Feel Good, Play Good. Smell Good?
description: Baseball is full of traditions and superstitions. For numerous players, a heavy dose of cologne or women’s perfume is the unlikeliest of performance-enhancers.
content: It was sometime during the 2012 season when Alcides Escobar of the Kansas City Royals grabbed a bottle from his locker and sprayed some of its contents onto Salvador Pérez. Caught off guard, Pérez warned his fellow Venezuelan and close friend not to mess with him, punctuating his emotion with some colorful language in Spanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Says Goodbye to Multiple Cast Members
description: Kate McKinnon, Pete Davidson and Aidy Bryant each got to take a victory lap in a “Saturday Night Live” season finale hosted by Natasha Lyonne.
content: We’ll start this weekend’s recap of “Saturday Night Live” at the end, and a season finale that concluded with a particularly tearful set of goodnight waves from the cast. While several of them were merely saying goodbye for the summer, a few longtime performers made it clear during the broadcast that this was their last episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: ‘Belfast Girls’ Set Sail, but This Isn’t a Pleasure Cruise
description: A historical drama revisits a 19th-century scheme in which Irish girls of “good character” were encouraged to immigrate to Australia.
content: In 1850, it took about three months to travel to Australia from Ireland. Jaki McCarrick’s heartfelt, doubtful “Belfast Girls,” at the Irish Repertory Theater, sets sail with the Inchinnan, bedding down in a windowless cabin with several characters as part of a real-life resettlement plan then known as the Earl Grey Scheme or the Famine Orphan Scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: What Donald Trump Didn’t Count On in Georgia
description: Brian Kemp, the incumbent governor, is at the top of the former president’s enemies list. But to many Georgia Republicans, he is ‘one of us.’
content: THOMASTON, Ga.— Brian Kemp, Georgia’s incumbent governor and a prominent fixture on former President Donald J. Trump’s enemies list, was clip-clopping around in a pair of cowboy boots in this small city on a recent morning, glad-handing his way through an adoring Republican throng at a place called Greatest Generation Memorial Park. Soon he was confronted by a smiling man wearing a baseball cap adorned with a cursive letter “A.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Nate Schweber
title: Man Fatally Shot on Manhattan Subway in Unprovoked Attack
description: A gunman shot and killed Daniel Enriquez, 48, on a Q train in Lower Manhattan on Sunday. “It’s horrific, this is a horror movie,” his sister said.
content: As the Q train rumbled across the East River on a sunny Sunday morning, with a view of the Lower Manhattan skyline shimmering through the windows, a man paced up and down the aisle of the last car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: In Iran, a New Wave of Repression Hits Acclaimed Filmmakers
description: The authorities in the Islamic Republic like to take credit for the country’s achievements in film, but are warning those who make them not to cross red lines at home.
content: In the shadow of a crackdown in Iran this month on demonstrations by ordinary citizens against rising food prices, the authorities there also have gone after a widely celebrated sector of Iranian society: the filmmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Lara Logan, Once a Star at CBS News, Is Now One for the Far Right
description: The former chief foreign affairs correspondent is now a popular guest on podcasts hosted by vaccine skeptics and deniers of the 2020 election.
content: When Lara Logan reached the heights of American journalism more than a decade ago, as the chief foreign affairs correspondent for CBS News, her bosses didn’t think twice about sending her to cover the biggest stories in the world. Producers clamored to work with her as she landed interviews with a Taliban commander, chronicled the Arab Spring and tracked the Ebola outbreak. Former President Barack Obama called her to wish her well after the most traumatic event of what seemed like a limitless career: She was sexually assaulted while covering a demonstration in Cairo’s Tahrir Square in 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: How My Father, Ronald Reagan, Grappled With Abortion
description: Even as his beliefs on abortion shaped global policy, he was never entirely at peace with the issue.
content: Like every offspring of a famous political figure, I frequently round a corner and slam straight into some aspect of my father’s legacy. I’ve not checked with other political offspring, but I’m guessing we all shuffle through the same questions: Do I speak out, try to offer a wider or more personal perspective? Or do I keep quiet, let the news cycle move on without me and shy away from questions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sammy Westfall
title: Rural Philippines, Long Neglected, Newly Appealing in Covid Times
description: The economic disparity of the nation’s rural and urban areas is a problem of long standing. Will the lessons of the pandemic finally lead to change?
content: LEYTE, the Philippines — For nearly all the pandemic, Marlen Zilmar woke up to the sound of roosters. Before the sun reached its fierce apogee, she’d swing a makeshift watering can made of a perforated plastic bottle over the garden in her family home, where she had returned after the coronavirus hit Manila.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Australia’s New Leader
description: Plus President Biden’s trip to Asia and catastrophic floods in India and Bangladesh.
content: Prime Minister Scott Morrison conceded defeat to Anthony Albanese, the incoming Labor prime minister, ending nine years of conservative leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias
title: Southern Baptist Leaders Mishandled Sex Abuse Crisis, Report Alleges
description: Executives of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination ignored victims, resisted reforms and were concerned with avoiding ‘potential liability,’ the third-party investigation says.
content: National leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention suppressed reports of sexual abuse and resisted proposals for reform over two decades, according to a third-party investigation published by the convention Sunday. The report also said that a former president of the denomination was accused of sexually assaulting a woman in 2010, a claim the report described as “credible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul O'Neill and Jack Curry
title: A Memorable Chat With the ‘Voice of God’
description: In his new book, the former Yankee Paul O’Neill recounts a conversation with the Hall of Famer Ted Williams that involved some crucial advice: “Don’t let anyone change you.”
content: His voice was powerful and direct, kind of like the voice of God. In some ways, he was a god. A hitting god named Ted Williams calling my cellphone, as stunning and as welcome a call as I’ve ever received.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: In the Fight Over How to Teach Reading, This Guru Makes a Major Retreat
description: Lucy Calkins, a leading literacy expert, has rewritten her curriculum to include a fuller embrace of phonics and the science of reading. Critics may not be appeased.
content: For decades, Lucy Calkins has determined how millions of children learn to read. An education professor, she has been a pre-eminent leader of “balanced literacy,” a loosely defined teaching philosophy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Russia Renews Assault on Key Eastern City as Advances by Both Sides Slow
description: The battle for Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine represents another crucial point in the war, as both sides engage in a grueling war of attrition.
content: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Ukrainian and Russian forces traded fresh blows on Sunday near Sievierodonetsk, military authorities and analysts said, as Moscow renewed its push toward the city, one of the last major Ukrainian strongholds in a key part of the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City Claims Title After Nearly Kicking It Away
description: Three second-half goals capped a dramatic final day in the Premier League, and denied Liverpool an improbable championship.
content: MANCHESTER, England — In that wild, euphoric moment, as the stands rattled and shook, Manchester City felt it again, that sensation it had known once, not all that long ago, the one enshrined in a shimmering statue on the plaza outside the Etihad Stadium. They would, they had been told, never see its like again. They could, it turned out, come very close indeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak
title: ‘Such Bad Guys Will Come’: How One Russian Brigade Terrorized Bucha
description: A particularly fearsome unit of Moscow’s invading army arrived in the Kyiv suburb in mid-March. The soldiers’ reputation preceded them.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — When the soldiers of Russia’s 64th Motorized Rifle Brigade arrived in Bucha in mid-March, they brought a new level of death and terror to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Broome County Contends With the Roots of a Racist Massacre
description: After a man from Conklin, N.Y., was charged with a mass killing at a Buffalo grocery store, the community where he grew up has been forced to wrestle with hard questions.
content: CONKLIN, N.Y. — Not long after the police identified a suspect in the racist massacre at a Buffalo grocery store, the phones in some local government offices here started ringing. On the other end were people making threats, enraged because they assumed that the suspect’s hometown near the Pennsylvania border, some 200 miles from the scene of the shooting, had stoked his racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia’s ‘Climate Election’ Finally Arrived. Will It Be Enough?
description: Voters rejected the deny-and-delay approach that has made Australia a global laggard on emission cuts. But how far the new government will go remains to be seen.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — A few minutes after taking the stage to declare victory in Australia’s election on Saturday, Anthony Albanese, the incoming Labor prime minister, promised to transform climate change from a source of political conflict into a generator of economic growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: In Cleveland, Schubert Outsings Even the Mighty ‘Otello’
description: After playing Schubert’s Ninth Symphony just before the pandemic lockdown, the Cleveland Orchestra shone in its return to the sprawling work.
content: CLEVELAND — On the morning of Friday, March 13, 2020, the Cleveland Orchestra played Schubert’s Ninth Symphony. The musicians were in concert dress, but just a handful of people were in the seats of Severance Hall. Pandemic bans on public gatherings were going into effect, and this would be the last concert here before the long lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Celtics’ Stars Provide the Drama. Heat’s Stars Deliver the Win.
description: A strange playoff series keeps getting weirder with injury scares and furious comebacks. It’s difficult to tell who is best prepared to adapt.
content: BOSTON — On the first possession of the game, Miami Heat point guard Kyle Lowry made a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: White Sox Call Josh Donaldson’s ‘Jackie’ Comments Racist
description: Donaldson, the Yankees’ third baseman, said his remarks to Tim Anderson referenced a magazine article in which Anderson said he was “today’s Jackie Robinson.”
content: White Sox Manager Tony La Russa didn’t mince words when he was asked what happened between Yankees third baseman Josh Donaldson and Chicago shortstop Tim Anderson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Goldman
title: ‘Everybody Should Be Concerned’ About Monkeypox, Biden Warns
description: Only one case of the virus has so far been identified in the U.S., but public health officials say the disease is likely to spread.
content: President Biden raised the alarm on Sunday about monkeypox, a viral infection fast spreading around the world, and warned that the disease, which can be spread as easily as through handling a contaminated object, is something “that everybody should be concerned about.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Political Crisis Is Resolved, but Governing Remains a Strain
description: A lawmaker who quit the coalition last week reversed her decision on Sunday, averting the government’s imminent collapse.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s latest government crisis was resolved on Sunday, at least temporarily, when a lawmaker who quit the coalition late last week agreed to return to it, snatching back the tiny majority that its opposition held over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Arrives in Tokyo Seeking to Shore Up Support for Economic Plan
description: The president will meet with his counterparts from Australia, India and Japan.
content: TOYKO — President Biden on Sunday began the second chapter of his diplomatic tour in Asia, pivoting from reassuring allies about the threat posed by North Korea to rallying nations behind his administration’s new economic policy for the Indo-Pacific.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1897: Cambridge University Votes Against Degrees for Women
description: A resolution to grant degrees to women was rejected by a large majority and men celebrated the result with fireworks.
content: [BY THE HERALD’S SPECIAL WIRE.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Secret City,’ an Epic Narrative History of the Closet in the Capital
description: James Kirchick’s new book tallies the cost of homophobia on lives and careers in Washington, D.C., from the days of F.D.R. to the Clinton presidency.
content: SECRET CITYThe Hidden History of Gay WashingtonBy James Kirchick826 pages. Henry Holt. $38.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Mystery of Star Cyclist’s Murder Deepens as Police Seek Suspect
description: Kaitlin Marie Armstrong is being sought in the killing of Anna Moriah Wilson, according to the police, who said both women were romantically involved with the same man.
content: A rising cycling star who was visiting Texas for a competition was found shot dead in Austin this month, rattling the tight-knit community of off-road biking and racing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wisdom From the Visionaries Series
description: Thoughts from our Visionaries series, conversations with people transforming their fields.

title: Documenting Atrocities in the War in Ukraine
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has generated enormous demand in both Ukraine and friendly Western governments for an accounting of Russian military actions that could be prosecuted as war crimes — actions so  egregious they violate the commonly accepted laws concerning armed combat.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has generated enormous demand in both Ukraine and friendly Western governments for an accounting of Russian military actions that could be prosecuted as war crimes — actions so  egregious they violate the commonly accepted laws concerning armed combat.

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Karen Yourish and Keith Collins
title: How Trump’s 2020 Election Lies Have Gripped State Legislatures
description: A Times review of legislative votes and records reveals how lies about the 2020 election took hold in statehouses, driving efforts to unravel a free and fair election.
content: A Times review of legislative votes and records reveals how lies about the 2020 election took hold in statehouses, driving efforts to unravel a free and fair election.

author: By Network Pool
title: Biden Warns That Monkeypox Spread Would be ‘Consequential’
description: Before departing South Korea on Sunday, President Biden sounded the alarm about monkeypox, a viral infection that is quickly spreading around the world.
content: Before departing South Korea on Sunday, President Biden sounded the alarm about monkeypox, a viral infection that is quickly spreading around the world.

author: By Storyful, The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Powerful Storms Rip Through Eastern Canada
description: A line of thunderstorms cut a violent path across parts of Ontario and Quebec on Saturday, killing multiple people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power, according to Environment Canada.
content: A line of thunderstorms cut a violent path across parts of Ontario and Quebec on Saturday, killing multiple people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power, according to Environment Canada.

author: By NYPD
title: Man Fatally Shot on Manhattan Subway Train
description: The 48-year-old victim was shot in the chest while riding a Q train in Lower Manhattan, the police said. Investigators believe the attack was unprovoked.
content: The 48-year-old victim was shot in the chest while riding a Q train in Lower Manhattan, the police said. Investigators believe the attack was unprovoked.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Thoughts on outdoor griddles, and recipes for the days ahead: creamy chive pasta, ginger-garlic shrimp and more.
content: Good morning. I don’t generally offer investment advice, but this is close to a sure thing: You should issue a buy order for a heavy cast-iron griddle if you have access to a gas or charcoal grill. You can use it to prepare outdoor breakfasts of bacon and eggs, and lunchtime grilled cheeses or impressively crisp smash burgers. At night you can make like the chef Francis Mallmann and sizzle a flattened pork butt, as in his recipe for pork and peaches.
source.name: The New York Times
